Consumers & Patients

With social media and digital tools at the fingertips of consumers and patients, Merck has to change the way it communicates with them. To reach consumers and patients, we have to go to where they spend their time and engage with them in a conversation. Check out some of the ways you can engage with consumers and patients.

  • Social Media
  • sem
  • consumer websites
  • seo
  • influcener and pr campagins
  • banner ads
  • metrics 101
Healthcare Professionals
Social Media

Social Media

Social media marketing is a way we can connect with patients and consumers through social media platforms. This can help build your brand or drive website traffic. Social media marketing involves publishing great content on your social media profile, listening and engaging your followers, analyzing your results and running advertisements on social media platforms.

Check out some strategies you can use to engage them.
  • FACEBOOK
  • INSTAGRAM
  • TWITTER
  • LINKEDIN
  • YOUTUBE
  • PINTEREST
  • SPOTIFY
FACEBOOK

Best for:

  • Brand awareness
  • Video campaigns
  • Lead generation
  • Building relationships

Facebook Audience:

Age:

18-29 years old

(about 79% of users)

Gender:

50% female; 50% male

Device used most:

desktop

Best Practices:

  • Keep posts short and concise
  • Post during evening hours
  • Engage audience with questions
  • Share informative content
  • Post during the weekends for maximum reach
  • Avoid overly promotional content as organic posts

Instagram Audience:

Age:

13-17 years old

(about 72% of users )

71% of young adults 18-24 years old used Instagram in 2018

Gender:

50% female; 50% male

Device used most:

mobile

Best Practices

  • Choose images/illustrations over text
  • Showcase and highlight audience & services 
  • Utilize hashtags
  • Utilize stories for showcasing 
  • Do not post as frequently
  • Post near high engagement periods such as end of day or early morning hours
TWITTER

Best for:

  • News, updates
  • Articles
  • Infographics
  • Facts and statistics

Twitter Targeting Abilities: 

Twitter Audience:

Age:

18-29 (36% of users)

Gender:

50% female; 50% male

Education:

popular among educated people (29% of users have college degrees; 20% of users have high school degrees or less)

Device used most:

mobile

Best Practices

  • Copy should comply with the character count
  • Higher focus on brand awareness and impressions
  • Lower cost per click and cost per 1,000 impressions than most mediums
  • Focus on engaging, snackable content and less dense information-wise
  • Audience has a high affinity for sports, celebrities and politics

Best for:

  • Business development (B2B)
  • Brand awareness
  • Updates
  • Sharing articles and news
  • Lead generation

LinkedIn Targeting Abilities: 

LinkedIn Audience:

Age:

30-49 Years Old

Gender:

50% female; 50% male

Education:

popular among educated

urban professionals Studies show that 80% of B2B leads come from LinkedIn and 94% of B2B marketers use LinkedIn to distribute content and promote their vision

Best Practices

  • A professional medium
  • Company culture-orientated
  • Best platform to share educational news & insights 
  • Highlighting HR content
  • Posts about events and conferences
  • Choose images/illustrations over text
  • Focus on corporate social responsibility and social involvement
YOUTUBE

Best for:

  • Learning
  • Storytelling
  • TED Talk style videos
  • Behind-the-scenes content

YouTube Targeting Abilities: 

YouTube Audience:

Age:

18-34 Years Old

About 80% of the User

Gender:

50% female; 50% male (slightly higher among males)

Best Practices (Organic)

  • Commit to a regular posting schedule
  • Make sure you have a cohesive mission and purpose to your channel
  • Add a call-to-action in each video, such as a visit to a website
  • Diversify your videos to see what resonates best with your audience and then adjust your strategy and posting schedule accordingly
  • Create the video for mobile first,

Best Practices (Advertising)

  • Utilize remarketing to re-engage with customers who may have interacted with your video in a particular way (for example, clicked through to your ad, watched the entire ad)
  • Optimize performance constantly by reviewing ad performance in Google analytics
  • Keep tabs on the right metrics to determine success, one of which being cost per video view
  • Keep mobile top-of-mind when creating a video or advertisement as over 70% of YouTube viewers are on mobile
pinterest

Best for:

  • Brand awareness
  • E-commerce

Pinterest Targeting Abilities: 

  • Customer lists
  • People who went to your site
  • People who engaged with your Pins on Pinterest
  • People similar to an existing audience list

Pinterest Audience:

Age:

18-29 (34% of users); 30-49 (35% of users)

Gender:

majority of users are female

Best Practices

  • Use one Pin per campaign
  • Group campaigns by keywords and themes
  • Remember that creative aspects are more powerful than keywords
  • Use vertical aspect ratio in your Pins
  • Repurpose best organic Pins for advertising
  • Leverage interest targets
  • Separate mobile & desktop campaigns
SPOTIFY

Best for:

  • Audio ads (repurposing radio content)
  • Display ads
  • Video ads
  • Influencer marketing
  • Podcast interest-targeting

Spotify Targeting Abilities: 

Spotify Audience:

Age:

under 30 years-old

Nearly twice as many under 30 year-olds use Spotify when compared to Apple Music.

Best Practices

  • Use multiple Spotify ad formats per campaign to target an audience
  • Enable cross-device targeting to reach audiences both in home (desktop) and out-of-home (mobile)
  • Target playlists and genres that are in sync with your brand and message
Search Engine Marketing

Search Engine Marketing

Search Engine Marketing (SEM) is a way of gaining website traffic through paid search ads. Merck pays to show ads to users who are actively searching for the keywords that are being targeted. The targeted keywords can be branded or unbranded. Google AdWords is the most popular paid search platform used by search marketers.

Branded & Unbranded Search Campaigns
Branded: 
  • Bid Against Brand Name 
  • Show Branded Ad Copy
  • Direct Users to Branded Website 
Unbranded:
  • Bid Against Indication / Disease State 
  • Show Unbranded Ad Copy
  • Direct Users to Unbranded Campaign Site 
Components of a Search Campaign:
  • Campaign Strategy
  • Ad Group
  • Ads & Extensions

Campaign Strategy

  • Set Campaign Objective
  • Determine Targeting Locations 
  • Language of Search Campaign / Audience
  • Audience Targeting: Narrow the reach of your campaign to the selected audiences, with the option to adjust the bids
  • Set Budget (Daily or Monthly) 
X

Ad Group

Organize ads by a common theme. For example, try separating ad groups into the different product or service types you offer

Ad groups contain a set list of targeted keywords for which you would like your ads to appear

Set match types of keywords:

Broad Match: ads may show on searches that include misspellings, synonyms, related searches and other relevant variations. For example, if your keyword is “womens hats,” someone searching for “buy ladies hats” might see your ad.

Phrase Match: ads may show on searches that match a phrase, or are close variations of that phrase, with additional words before or after. Ads will not show, however, if a word is added to the middle of the phrase, or if words in the phrase are reordered in any way.

Exact Match: ads may show on searches that match the exact term or are close variations of that exact term. Close variants include searches for keywords with the same meaning as the exact keywords, regardless of spelling or grammar differences between the query and the keyword.

X

Ads & Extensions

  • Ensure the copy relates to your keywords
  • Align landing pages to ad copy and ad group
  • Focus on headlines (avoid generic and repetitive headlines)
  • Use 3 headlines and 2 description lines per ad
  • Must have a minimum of 3-5 different ads per ad group
  • Utilize all relevant ad extensions (callout extensions, site link extensions) 
  • Create responsive search ads (1 per ad group)
X
Consumer Websites

Consumer Websites

UX for Consumer Websites
Know the Audience:

having a clear idea of the audience allows us to discover their needs and wants from the website, and create the perfect design that will meet their desires.

Design Elements that Are Focused on User Experience:

graphics, layout, text and interactive elements work in unity to present the user with an experience and not just present them with information. 

Create Clarity, Consistency, and Simplicity:

users should know what to expect when you are reusing colours, behaviours and aesthetics. This will reduce the need for them to figure out the interface and become quickly familiar with some of the aspects of the design, making it easier to use.

When designing a website for best UX practices, you should also keep in mind these main points:
  • Useful: content should fulfill a need
  • Usable: site must be easy to find and navigate
  • Desirable: design elements should bring about emotion and appreciation
  • Findable: content needs to be locatable and navigable offsite and onsite
  • Accessible: content needs to be accessible to people with disabilities
  • Credible: users must believe and trust the information you relay to them
Google Analytics

Google Analytics (GA) is a piece of software that helps marketers to keep track of online campaigns and analyze website performance. GA uses a small piece of code which has to be placed at the back-end of the website. Every time a user loads a webpage, the GA code sends data into the Google Analytics account where it can be analyzed.

Analytics can help marketers optimize website performance, create remarketing campaigns and measure campaigns performance.

Google Analytics has a variety of reports that can be used depending on the purpose. Some of the GA reports include:
  • Conversion Reports: how many times visitors accomplished desired goals on the website and what was the source of these users.
  • Demographics: age, gender, interests.
  • Geography: the country, province or city visitors live in.
  • Devices: the model, type and branding of visitors devices.
  • Source and Medium: where is the traffic coming from (a social media campaign, Google search campaigns, organic searching).
  • Pages: what pages do users visit the most and how do they engage with the content.
Search Engine Optimization

Search Engine Optimization

Search Engine Optimization (SEO) consists of multiple on-page and off-page processes that can help a website become more visible to potential patients or consumers on all search engines. Search engines use complicated algorithms to crawl websites and rank them based on content quality, technical structure, reputation, keyword placement, user navigability and readability.

When a user enters a search query into Google, Google will respond by providing a ranked list of websites for the user to browse through. The majority of users will not explore past the first page of Google, so it is important that the website ranks on the first page. Since the website is competing for rankings against other brands, products and services of a similar nature, it is important to always update content, update web pages based on algorithm updates or create additional content (such as blogs) to remain competitive.

Technical SEO involves more back-end processes, such as optimizing or compressing the images and files on a website so that it can run smoothly and load faster, ensuring that the website is fully secure and is following the proper protocols. These are vital factors in achieving a high search engine positioning and outranking competing brands.

Remarketing

Remarketing is an effective way to connect with visitors on your website who may not have made the desired digital action (for example, viewing a specific video) or those that did perform a specific action (for example, downloading a PDF). It allows you to position targeted ads in front of a defined engaged audience group that had previously visited your website as they browse elsewhere around the internet. Remarketing increases the likelihood that your audience will convert by increasing the number of times they see an ad for a product or service. 

Remarketing pixel codes from platforms such as Google AdWords, Acuity, Bing Ads, Facebook, Instagram and Twitter are installed on each page of a website. This code triggers when someone visits your website or takes an action. When the pixel is triggered, data is then pulled into the related platform’s audience tracking as well as having a “cookie” sent to the person’s browser. The cookie and data do not contain any sensitive information; it is an ID string to act as an identifier.

It is important to note that some ad platforms are sensitive about remarketing when it comes to pharma and medical conditions. Depending on the execution, some platforms may not allow remarketing. This is decided on a case-by-case basis to comply with their policies. Since remarketing uses the same creative as a digital campaign, it is easy to try to queue up a remarketing audience to see if it gets approved based on the specific execution.

Influencer and PR campaigns

Influencer and PR campaigns

Traditional influencer campaigns leverage the large following and popularity of social media users to promote a brand, product, service and its overall message.

Influencer Marketing and Merck

Influencers can be "patient advocates" – they can advocate for a therapeutic area, but cannot mention a specific product.

Influencers can advocate for:
  • Fundraising events or marathons
  • Unbranded awareness or prevention campaigns
Banner Ads

Banner Ads

Banner ads involve placing promotional banners on third-party websites or search engines in order to reach your target audience. These ads can help you reach consumers or patients, but they are faced with the challenge of getting your message across within the constraints of ad formats and Ad Standards regulatory guidelines.

banner ads best practices
  • Be Concise:

    a consumer will only pay attention to your ad for a moment. Ensure sure your message sticks with the consumer or patient, while complying to Ad Standards guidelines.

  • High Quality Assets:

    use high-quality imagery, legible typefaces and brand elements, while remaining under the 150kb file limit used by Google Ads. Assets that are clear and crisp have a higher engagement levels.

  • Understand Your Audience:

    display ads should be targeted and relevant. Understand your audience and tailor the content for them.

  • Stick to the Brand:

    whether the ads are branded or unbranded, all of the imagery, colours and messaging should be consistent with the brand.

  • Keep It Simple:

    banner ad sizes are small and there is not a lot of space to work with. Don’t say too much as a lot of content will make the ad look cluttered and can be overwhelming, confusing and difficult for consumers to read. Keep your messaging, imagery and call-to-actions (CTAs) as clear and simple as possible.

Metrics 101

Metrics 101

Reach, Engage, Convert
  • Reach: used as a measure of success for a brand awareness campaign. Reach is found at the top of the marketing funnel. Reach is the number of people who have seen your ads at least once.
  • Engage: used for measuring the consideration phase and often measured by users interacting with the ads. For some campaigns, this could include clicks to a website, commenting on a post or liking a page. Levels of engagement on the site can be measured to evaluate site visitors with intent to potentially convert. This could include time on page, number of pages visited or video views.
  • Convert: conversion is a completed activity that is important to the success of the campaign. Conversions track how many visitors completed the activity on the site (for example, downloaded a PDF or watched a video).
Website

Track insights about the website that can help you make future decisions. Things that can be tracked are:

  • Users: total number of unique devices
  • Sessions: total number of website visits
  • Page Views: total number of pages viewed
  • Average Sessions: the amount of time users spend on a website on average
  • Goal/Conversion: the desired interaction or activity on a website
  • Bounce: single page website visits with no interaction with the page
  • Bounce Rate: the percentage of bounces
Ad Metrics
  • Reach: the number of people who have seen your ads at least once. Reach is different from impressions.
  • Impressions: the number of times your ads were shown to people. 
  • Clicks: how many users clicked on a link in the ad.  
  • Cost Per Click (CPC): the average cost for a click. Calculated by dividing total spend by clicks.  
  • Click Through Rate (CTR): the percentage of clicks from the ads. The higher the CTR, the more engaged your audience was with your ad.  
  • Cost Per Thousand Impressions (CPM): the average cost to achieve 1,000 impressions (typically used to calculate success of a brand awareness campaign).  
  • Engagement: how the user interacts with the ad (such as likes, shares, comments, reactions)  
  • Engagement Rate: is the percentage of engagements received for the total impressions received.
